profile_bio.description:
Chief Market Strategist @ Creative Planning 

Investor | Writer | Reader | Thinker

tweet.text:
US Trade Deficit in Goods & Services...

First 10 months of 2024: ‚Äì$727 billion deficit.

First 10 months of 2025: ‚Äì$783 billion deficit.  

YoY Change in Deficit: +8%

US Imports of Goods & Services...

First 10 months of 2024: $3.41 trillion.

First 10 months of 2025: $3.64 trillion.

YoY Change in Imports: +7% 

All of the trade numbers in 2025 were distorted by the massive front-running of the tariffs that occurred in Q1. US corporations massively built up their inventories (increasing imports/trade deficit) in Q1 and spent the rest of the year working that off (lower imports/deficits).

We won't know the real trade picture until some point in 2026 and it's likely that price increases for consumers are still coming.

Video: https://t.co/f7XuPOqlar

tweet.text: Been through a couple commodity cycles where in a matter of 12-months everyone becomes "an expert" and piles into a narrative. Don't use ATH commodity prices (or even higher prices) to justify buying a resource stock. If you can't justify the investment based on commodity levels 25% lower (in some cases 50% lower) you pass. And if the commodity does go 25% lower from here the equities will probably go 50% lower so just live in reality not make believe. All of this is to say be cautious - the real money is made buying resource stocks when the underlying commodity/resource is near lows and then being willing to wait years to be right and make 1000%+ in a year or two when it turns.

profile_bio.description: Finding great companies early @MicroCapClub // Bringing investors and companies together @PlanetMicroCap // CIO @IntelligentCM

tweet.text: I'm not interested in buying something that is undervalued that will always be undervalued. I want to find undervalued companies that can get overvalued. Fairly valued isn‚Äôt good enough. Betting on "reversion to the mean" just means you're investing in average situations. The great ones have a great story (tailwind) + great fundamentals.

quoted_tweet.text:
Just zoom out...

The monthly log-scale chart helps put things into perspective ‚Äî without overthinking it, this is clearly a strong uptrend and is very much reminiscent of previous major secular bull markets in Gold.

(...and no signs of it slowing down yet either) https://t.co/kXT7sS9OOH

profile_bio.description:
Just Gold - Just Charts - Just For Investors.

Visit our website to access the Gold Market Chartbook.

tweet.text:
Learnings and conclusions from this week‚Äôs charts:

1. Sentiment is getting increasingly consensus bullish.

2. VIX & Credit Spreads are at complacent/confident levels.

3. Transports, shipping stocks, EM, and metals are breaking out.

4. Value is cheaper than usual vs history and vs growth stocks.

5. Growth stocks are expensive vs history and vs value stocks.

Overall, the mood remains distinctly bullish and increasingly so ‚Äîand perhaps justifiably so as more evidence emerges in favor of a global growth reacceleration (and better performance from traditional cyclicals and risk-on assets). 

But with growth stocks already richly priced, and value still cheap, the next phase of the bull market might look a little unfamiliar to some‚Ä¶

(click through to charts üëá)

tweet.text: "Life Magazine's 'Parting Shot'" was a popular, often poignant, final photo feature on the back page of the magazine, known for powerful single images that summarized a story or idea, appearing in the 1960s and 1970s before its weekly run ended. It showcased exceptional photography, capturing moments like a Nixon photo with an orangutan (1969) or scientific subjects, leaving a lasting impression as a "picture is worth a thousand words" moment.

profile_bio.description:
30 years in markets. ex-Fund Manager, now independent.
Focus on BIG trends, actionable ideas, and execution.

tweet.text:
Goldman Survey on Investor Preferences:

‚ÄúClient positioning this year reflects a strong preference for diversification across both growth and value sectors,‚Äù GS strategist Guillaume Jaisson wrote.
‚ÄúTechnology remains the top pick, though its lead has narrowed compared to last year ‚Äî mirroring the decline in enthusiasm for the US market.‚Äù

Survey respondents chose:
- Tech to be the best-performing sector at 31% (down from 41% in 2025)
- Equities to be the top asset class at 51% (down from 68% last year)
- Commodities to be the top asset class at 35% (up from 19% last year)
- Geographical preference for the U.S. dropped to 23% (from 58%). Asia ex-Japan got 38% (up from 13%)

*GS conducted the survey during its Global Strategy Conference in London, attended by over 400 clients.
